message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: An Introduction to Lorenzen's ‘Algebraic and Logistic Investigations on Free Lattices’ (1951)
Paper Abstract: This article proposes an historical and mathematical introduction to Lorenzen's Algebraische und logistische Untersuchungen uber freie Verbande. These Investigations appeared in 1951 in The journal of symbolic logic. They have immediately been recognised as a landmark in the history of infinitary proof theory, but their approach and method of proof have not been incorporated into the corpus of proof theory. More precisely, the admissibility of cut is proved by double induction, on the cut formula and on the complexity of the derivations, without using any ordinal assignment, contrary to the presentation of cut elimination in most standard texts on proof theory. 
We propose a translation (arXiv:1710.08138) and this introduction with the intent of giving a new impetus to their reception. We also propose a translation of a preliminary manuscript, A preorder-theoretic proof of consistency, with the kind permission of Lorenzen's daughter, Jutta Reinhardt. 
The Investigations are best known for providing a constructive proof of consistency for ramified type theory without axiom of reducibility. Lorenzen does so by showing that it is a part of a trivially consistent calculus that describes our knowledge of arithmetic without detour. The proof resorts only to the inductive definition of formulas and theorems. He proposes furthermore a definition of a semilattice, of a distributive lattice, of a pseudocomplemented semilattice, and of a countably complete boolean lattice as deductive calculuses, and shows how to present them for constructing the respective free object over a given preordered set. This work illustrates that lattice theory is a bridge between algebra and logic. 
The preliminary manuscript, given as an appendix, contains already the main ideas and applies them to a constructive proof of consistency for elementary number theory.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Search Results for "Proof Theory"

I found comprehensive information about proof theory from the search results. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Scope

Proof theory is a major branch of mathematical logic and theoretical computer science within which proofs are treated as formal mathematical objects, facilitating their analysis by mathematical techniques.(no content)Proofs are typically presented as inductively defined data structures such as lists, boxed lists, or trees, which are constructed according to the axioms and rules of inference of a given logical system.

### Key Characteristics

Proof theory is syntactic in nature, in contrast to model theory, which is semantic in nature.(no content)Purely formal proofs, written fully in symbolic language without the involvement of natural language, are considered in proof theory.

### Major Areas

Some of the major areas of proof theory include structural proof theory, ordinal analysis, provability logic, proof-theoretic semantics, reverse mathematics, proof mining, automated theorem proving, and proof complexity.

### Historical Development

Stanisław Jaśkowski (1929) and Gerhard Gentzen (1934) independently provided calculi of natural deduction, with Gentzen's approach introducing the idea of symmetry between the grounds for asserting propositions, expressed in introduction rules, and the consequences of accepting propositions in the elimination rules.

### Applications

Much research also focuses on applications in computer science, linguistics, and philosophy.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Proof theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Proof_theory"},{"title":"Proof theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_theory"},{"title":"Structural proof theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_proof_theory"},{"title":"Evolution as fact and theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_as_fact_and_theory"},{"title":"Type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_theory"},{"title":"Propositional proof system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_proof_system"},{"title":"Ordinal analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordinal_analysis"},{"title":"Borel determinacy theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borel_determinacy_theorem"},{"title":"Mathematical proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_proof"},{"title":"Elementary proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elementary_proof"}]

## Search Results for "Proof Theory"

I found comprehensive information about proof theory from the search results. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Scope

Proof theory is a major branch of mathematical logic and theoretical computer science within which proofs are treated as formal mathematical objects, facilitating their analysis by mathematical techniques.(no content)Proofs are typically presented as inductively defined data structures such as lists, boxed lists, or trees, which are constructed according to the axioms and rules of inference of a given logical system.

### Key Characteristics

Proof theory is syntactic in nature, in contrast to model theory, which is semantic in nature.(no content)Purely formal proofs, written fully in symbolic language without the involvement of natural language, are considered in proof theory.

### Major Areas

Some of the major areas of proof theory include structural proof theory, ordinal analysis, provability logic, proof-theoretic semantics, reverse mathematics, proof mining, automated theorem proving, and proof complexity.

### Historical Development

Stanisław Jaśkowski (1929) and Gerhard Gentzen (1934) independently provided calculi of natural deduction, with Gentzen's approach introducing the idea of symmetry between the grounds for asserting propositions, expressed in introduction rules, and the consequences of accepting propositions in the elimination rules.

### Applications

Much research also focuses on applications in computer science, linguistics, and philosophy.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of lattice theory:

## Mathematical Definition

A lattice is an abstract structure studied in the mathematical subdisciplines of order theory and abstract algebra. It consists of a partially ordered set in which every pair of elements has a unique supremum (also called a least upper bound or join) and a unique infimum (also called a greatest lower bound).

## Key Characteristics

Because meet and join both commute and associate, a lattice can be viewed as consisting of two commutative semigroups having the same domain. The absorption law is the only defining identity that is peculiar to lattice theory.

## Applications and Extensions

Lattice theory has several important applications:

- **Partial Orders and Complete Lattices**: In complete lattices, every set has a greatest lower bound and a least upper bound.

- **Specialized Lattice Types**: Special classes of lattices include modular lattices, distributive lattices, and Boolean lattices.

- **Representation Theory**: Duality theory for distributive lattices provides three different (but closely related) representations of bounded distributive lattices via Priestley spaces, spectral spaces, and pairwise Stone spaces.

## Related Areas

The search results show that "lattice theory" can refer to different areas in mathematics and physics, including lattice models in physics (such as lattice gauge theory and lattice field theory), as well as the pure mathematical study of ordered structures.

Links: [{"title":"Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Category:Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Residuated Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Residuated_Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Free Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Boolean algebra (structure) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra_(structure)"},{"title":"Complete Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"List of Boolean algebra topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Boolean_algebra_topics"},{"title":"Inclusion (Boolean algebra) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusion_(Boolean_algebra)"},{"title":"Boolean matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_matrix"},{"title":"Boolean-valued model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean-valued_model"}]

Here's a summary of the web search results for Boolean algebra:

## Definition

Boolean algebra is a branch of algebra in mathematics and mathematical logic.(no content)It differs from elementary algebra in that the values of the variables are the truth values true and false, usually denoted by 1 and 0, whereas in elementary algebra the values are numbers.

## Structure

A Boolean algebra is a set A equipped with two binary operations ∧ (called "meet" or "and"), ∨ (called "join" or "or"), a unary operation ¬ (called "complement" or "not") and two elements 0 and 1 in A.

## Historical Development

The term honors George Boole (1815–1864), an English mathematician, who introduced the algebraic system in a pamphlet published in 1847 and later in a substantial book published in 1854.(no content)The term Boolean algebra was first suggested by Henry M. Sheffer in 1913.

## Applications

Boolean algebra has been fundamental in the development of digital electronics and is provided for in all modern programming languages.(no content)It is also used in set theory and statistics.(no content)The two-element Boolean algebra has applications in logic and circuit design in electrical engineering.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Type theory"

Links: [{"title":"Type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_theory"},{"title":"Intuitionistic type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intuitionistic_type_theory"},{"title":"Kind (type theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kind_(type_theory)"},{"title":"Container (type theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Container_(type_theory)"},{"title":"Homotopy type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homotopy_type_theory"},{"title":"History of type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_type_theory"},{"title":"Type A and Type B personality theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_A_and_Type_B_personality_theory"},{"title":"List of types of systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_types_of_systems_theory"},{"title":"Polynomial functor (type theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_functor_(type_theory)"},{"title":"Category:Type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Type_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Type theory":

## Overview

In modern literature, "type theory" refers to a typed system based around lambda calculus.(no content)A type theory is a mathematical logic composed of rules of inference that result in judgments, and has judgments that define types and assign them to a collection of formal objects, known as terms.

## Historical Development

Type theory was initially created to avoid paradoxes in a variety of formal logics and rewrite systems.(no content)By 1908, Russell arrived at a ramified theory of types, and this system avoided contradictions suggested in Russell's paradox by creating a hierarchy of types and then assigning each concrete mathematical entity to a specific type.

## Key Variants

One influential system is Per Martin-Löf's intuitionistic type theory, which was proposed as a foundation for constructive mathematics.(no content)Thierry Coquand's calculus of constructions is used as the foundation by Rocq (previously known as Coq), Lean, and other computer proof assistants.(no content)Homotopy type theory (HoTT) includes various lines of development of intuitionistic type theory, based on the interpretation of types as objects to which the intuition of abstract homotopy theory applies.

## Modern Applications

Much of the current research into type theory is driven by proof checkers, interactive proof assistants, and automated theorem provers.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Type theory was initially created to avoid paradoxes in a variety of formal logics and rewrite systems.(no content)By 1908, Russell arrived at a ramified theory of types, and this system avoided contradictions suggested in Russell's paradox by creating a hierarchy of types and then assigning each concrete mathematical entity to a specific type.

## Key Variants

One influential system is Per Martin-Löf's intuitionistic type theory, which was proposed as a foundation for constructive mathematics.(no content)Thierry Coquand's calculus of constructions is used as the foundation by Rocq (previously known as Coq), Lean, and other computer proof assistants.(no content)Homotopy type theory (HoTT) includes various lines of development of intuitionistic type theory, based on the interpretation of types as objects to which the intuition of abstract homotopy theory applies.

## Modern Applications

Much of the current research into type theory is driven by proof checkers, interactive proof assistants, and automated theorem provers.

## Cut Elimination

Based on the search results, here's what cut elimination is:

### Definition

The cut-elimination theorem states that any sequent that possesses a proof in the sequent calculus making use of the cut rule also possesses a cut-free proof, that is, a proof that does not make use of the cut rule.(no content)The meaning of the cut rule is that, if a formula A appears as a conclusion in one proof and a hypothesis in another, then another proof in which the formula A does not appear can be deduced.

### Key Significance

Cut elimination is important in mathematical logic and proof theory for several reasons:

1. **Consistency**: Once a system is shown to have a cut elimination theorem, it is normally immediate that the system is consistent.

2. **Proof Properties**: Normally also the system has, at least in first-order logic, the subformula property, an important property in several approaches to proof-theoretic semantics.

3. **Applications**: Cut elimination is one of the most powerful tools for proving interpolation theorems.

### Practical Considerations

Typically such a proof will be longer, of course, and not necessarily trivially so. In fact, George Boolos demonstrated that there was a derivation that could be completed in a page using cut, but whose analytic proof could not be completed in the lifespan of the universe.

Links: [{"title":"Semilattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semilattice"},{"title":"Maximal semilattice quotient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximal_semilattice_quotient"},{"title":"Free lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_lattice"},{"title":"Finite set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuratowski-finite?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Congruence lattice problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congruence_Lattice_Problem"},{"title":"Conflict-free replicated data type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict-free_replicated_data_type?amp="},{"title":"Distributivity (order theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributivity_(order_theory)"},{"title":"Power domains - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_domains"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about semilattices:

## Definition

A join-semilattice (or upper semilattice) is a partially ordered set that has a join (a least upper bound) for any nonempty finite subset.(no content)Dually, a meet-semilattice (or lower semilattice) is a partially ordered set which has a meet (or greatest lower bound) for any nonempty finite subset.

## Algebraic Properties

A semilattice is a commutative, idempotent semigroup; i.e., a commutative band.(no content)A bounded semilattice is an idempotent commutative monoid.

## Operations and Order Relations

The greatest lower bound of the set {x, y} is called the meet of x and y, denoted x ∧ y.(no content)The least upper bound of {x, y} is called the join of x and y, denoted x ∨ y.(no content)A partial order is induced on a meet-semilattice by setting x ≤ y whenever x ∧ y = x. For a join-semilattice, the order is induced by setting x ≤ y whenever x ∨ y = y.

## Boundedness

A join-semilattice is bounded if it has a least element, the join of the empty set.(no content)Dually, a meet-semilattice is bounded if it has a greatest element, the meet of the empty set.

## Applications

Semilattices have practical applications in distributed computing. The merge function provides a join for any pair of replica states, so the set of all states forms a semilattice. This is relevant in conflict-free replicated data types (CRDTs) used in distributed systems.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Distributive lattice"

Links: [{"title":"Distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Completely distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Completely_distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Birkhoff's representation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birkhoff's_representation_theorem"},{"title":"Distributivity (order theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributivity_(order_theory)"},{"title":"Modular lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_lattice"},{"title":"Semilattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semilattice"},{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Duality theory for distributive lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_theory_for_distributive_lattices"},{"title":"Antimatroid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimatroid"},{"title":"Congruence lattice problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congruence_lattice_problem"}]

Here are the search results for "Distributive lattice":

## Definition

A distributive lattice is a lattice in which the operations of join and meet distribute over each other.(no content)The prototypical examples of such structures are collections of sets for which the lattice operations can be given by set union and intersection.

## Key Characteristics

A lattice is distributive if one of the converse inequalities holds, meaning the lattice satisfies certain distributivity conditions beyond what all lattices must satisfy. A lattice is distributive if and only if none of its sublattices is isomorphic to M3 or N5, where M3 is the "diamond lattice" and N5 is the "pentagon lattice."

## Examples

Several important types of structures are distributive lattices:

- Every Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice.
- Every Heyting algebra is a distributive lattice. Especially this includes all locales and hence all open set lattices of topological spaces.
- Every totally ordered set is a distributive lattice with max as join and min as meet.
- The natural numbers form a (conditionally complete) distributive lattice by taking the greatest common divisor as meet and the least common multiple as join.

## Representation Theory

Birkhoff's representation theorem for distributive lattices states that the elements of any finite distributive lattice can be represented as finite sets, in such a way that the lattice operations correspond to unions and intersections of sets.

Links: [{"title":"Distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Completely distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Completely_distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Birkhoff's representation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birkhoff's_representation_theorem"},{"title":"Distributivity (order theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributivity_(order_theory)"},{"title":"Modular lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_lattice"},{"title":"Semilattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semilattice"},{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Duality theory for distributive lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_theory_for_distributive_lattices"},{"title":"Antimatroid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimatroid"},{"title":"Congruence lattice problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congruence_lattice_problem"}]

Here are the search results for "Distributive lattice":

## Definition

A distributive lattice is a lattice in which the operations of join and meet distribute over each other.(no content)The prototypical examples of such structures are collections of sets for which the lattice operations can be given by set union and intersection.

## Key Characteristics

A lattice is distributive if one of the converse inequalities holds, meaning the lattice satisfies certain distributivity conditions beyond what all lattices must satisfy. A lattice is distributive if and only if none of its sublattices is isomorphic to M3 or N5, where M3 is the "diamond lattice" and N5 is the "pentagon lattice."

## Examples

Several important types of structures are distributive lattices:

- Every Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice.
- Every Heyting algebra is a distributive lattice. Especially this includes all locales and hence all open set lattices of topological spaces.
- Every totally ordered set is a distributive lattice with max as join and min as meet.
- The natural numbers form a (conditionally complete) distributive lattice by taking the greatest common divisor as meet and the least common multiple as join.

## Representation Theory

Birkhoff's representation theorem for distributive lattices states that the elements of any finite distributive lattice can be represented as finite sets, in such a way that the lattice operations correspond to unions and intersections of sets.

Links: [{"title":"Church's thesis (constructive mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church's_thesis_(constructive_mathematics)"},{"title":"Constructivism (philosophy of mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructivism_(philosophy_of_mathematics)"},{"title":"Constructive proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructive_proof"},{"title":"Constructive analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructive_analysis"},{"title":"Constructive mathematics","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Constructive_mathematics&redirect=no"},{"title":"Constructive function theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructive_function_theory"},{"title":"Heyting arithmetic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heyting_arithmetic"},{"title":"Errett Bishop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Errett_Bishop"},{"title":"Constructive nonstandard analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructive_non-standard_analysis"},{"title":"Reuben Goodstein - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuben_Goodstein"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of constructive mathematics:

## Definition and Core Principle

In the philosophy of mathematics, constructivism asserts that it is necessary to find (or "construct") a specific example of a mathematical object in order to prove that an example exists.(no content)In contrast, classical mathematics allows one to prove the existence of a mathematical object without "finding" that object explicitly, by assuming its non-existence and then deriving a contradiction from that assumption.

## Key Differences from Classical Mathematics

A constructive proof is a method of proof that demonstrates the existence of a mathematical object by creating or providing a method for creating the object.(no content)Much constructive mathematics uses intuitionistic logic, which is essentially classical logic without the law of the excluded middle.

## Different Forms

Forms of constructivism include the program of intuitionism founded by Brouwer, the finitism of Hilbert and Bernays, the constructive recursive mathematics of Shanin and Markov, and Bishop's program of constructive analysis.

## Practical Applications

Constructive proofs can be seen as defining certified mathematical algorithms, an idea explored in the Brouwer–Heyting–Kolmogorov interpretation of constructive logic, the Curry–Howard correspondence between proofs and programs, and intuitionistic type theory.(no content)Errett Bishop is best known for developing constructive analysis in his 1967 Foundations of Constructive Analysis, where he proved most of the important theorems in real analysis using constructivist methods.

Web search results for query: "Free lattices"

Links: [{"title":"Free lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_lattice"},{"title":"Complete lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_lattice"},{"title":"Lattice (group) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(group)"},{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Completely distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Completely_distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Modular lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_lattice"},{"title":"Lattice (discrete subgroup) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(discrete_subgroup)"},{"title":"Lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice"},{"title":"Geometric lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_lattice"}]

Here are the search results for "Free lattices":

## Overview

In mathematics, in the area of order theory, a free lattice is the free object corresponding to a lattice.(no content)As free objects, they have the universal property.

## Key Properties

Some notable properties of free lattices include:

- The free lattice of a three-element set of generators is infinite, and one can show that every free lattice on three generators contains a sublattice which is free for a set of four generators.

- The complete free lattice (on three or more generators) "does not exist", in the sense that it is a proper class.

## The Word Problem

The word problem for free lattices has some interesting aspects.(no content)The word problem for free bounded lattices is the problem of determining which elements of well-formed expressions denote the same element in the free bounded lattice.

## Special Cases

Different types of free lattices have been studied:

- The free distributive lattice over a set of generators can be constructed much more easily than a general free lattice.

- A paper published by Dedekind in 1900 had lattices as its central topic: he described the free modular lattice generated by three elements, a lattice with 28 elements.

Here's an overview of elementary number theory based on the search results:

## Definition and Scope

Elementary number theory studies aspects of integers that can be investigated using elementary methods such as elementary proofs.(no content)Elementary number theory includes topics of number theory commonly taught at the primary and secondary school level, or in college courses on introductory number theory.

## Primary Topics

Elementary number theory deals with the topics in number theory by means of basic methods in arithmetic, with its primary subjects of study being divisibility, factorization, and primality, as well as congruences in modular arithmetic.(no content)Other topics in elementary number theory include Diophantine equations, continued fractions, integer partitions, and Diophantine approximations.

## Historical Context

Euclid devoted part of his Elements to topics that belong to elementary number theory, including prime numbers and divisibility, giving the Euclidean algorithm for computing the greatest common divisor of two numbers and a proof implying the infinitude of primes.

## Relationship to Other Approaches

Analytic number theory, by contrast, relies on complex numbers and techniques from analysis and calculus.(no content)Algebraic number theory employs algebraic structures such as fields and rings to analyze the properties of and relations between numbers.

Here's an overview of elementary number theory based on the search results:

## Definition and Scope

Elementary number theory studies aspects of integers that can be investigated using elementary methods such as elementary proofs.(no content)Elementary number theory includes topics of number theory commonly taught at the primary and secondary school level, or in college courses on introductory number theory.

## Primary Topics

Elementary number theory deals with the topics in number theory by means of basic methods in arithmetic, with its primary subjects of study being divisibility, factorization, and primality, as well as congruences in modular arithmetic.(no content)Other topics in elementary number theory include Diophantine equations, continued fractions, integer partitions, and Diophantine approximations.

## Historical Context

Euclid devoted part of his Elements to topics that belong to elementary number theory, including prime numbers and divisibility, giving the Euclidean algorithm for computing the greatest common divisor of two numbers and a proof implying the infinitude of primes.

## Relationship to Other Approaches

Analytic number theory, by contrast, relies on complex numbers and techniques from analysis and calculus.(no content)Algebraic number theory employs algebraic structures such as fields and rings to analyze the properties of and relations between numbers.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "An Introduction to Lorenzen's 'Algebraic and Logistic Investigations on Free Lattices' (1951)". Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Extracted Entities (10 triples):**

1. **Proof theory** (concept, uses) - Foundation for the paper's improvements to proof methods
2. **Cut-elimination theorem** (method, proposes) - Novel double induction approach without ordinal assignments
3. **Type theory** (concept, uses) - Consistency proofs for ramified type theory
4. **Lattice (order)** (concept, uses) - Core to algebraic investigations of free lattices
5. **Boolean algebra** (concept, uses) - Definitions of countably complete Boolean lattices
6. **Constructivism** (concept, uses) - Constructive proofs of consistency
7. **Free lattice** (artifact, proposes) - Methods to construct free objects over preordered sets
8. **Number theory** (task, uses) - Applied to consistency proofs
9. **Semilattice** (concept, proposes) - New definition as deductive calculi
10. **Distributive lattice** (concept, proposes) - New definition as deductive calculi

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and functional
- Paper type correctly set as "contribution"
- All required relations present (both "uses" and "proposes")
- Entity types properly categorized

Sources:
- [Proof theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_theory)
